content: Hey @T-compiler/meeting ! Time for our ~monthly planning meeting. Add a :wave: to show you're here
sorry I'm late; while trying to put together a proposal (compiler-team#483), I got distracted by ideas for the doc itself. :smile:
Does anyone have any announcements before we start?
okay lets see about proposals
unscheduled proposals list
there's currently two items on it, and one of them (compiler-team#479) I think it a clerical error
(i.e. we had our P-high meeting already. Though I never made a post about it.)
the #t-compiler > reviewing P-high issues 2022 (Q1) is still on-going; there has been some awesome work from @Jack Huey on getting through a bunch of those issues
so in reality, we only have one actual proposal
(the one I was late to the meeting because I was drafting it)
Review 2022 Ambititions for T-Compiler compiler-team#483
this specific meeting I would really like to have on 2022-02-18
(because I want to put the post up)
Is there anyone in this meeting right now who objects to that timeline?
We're also going to be talking about it at the CTCFT meeting on 02-21. So it would be good to have had this discussion by then.
oh yeah, that's another good reason to prioritize the steering meeting to be on 2022-02-18. :laughing:
I also want to talk about whether we want to allocate the other meeting slots to anything in particular
the 1.59 release is on 2022-02-24
We could always allocate time to to through "oldest unreviewed PRs"
yep.
or to reviewing the MCPs queue
I will be unavailable for meeting on 2022-02-25
but Wesley can cover me
So I guess my question is: Is there any other topic that anyone thinks we should dedicate a meeting to?
Otherwise, I would say that we do the 2022 Ambitions doc review on 2022-02-18
and do a "backlog bonanza" (to reuse T-lang terms) on 2022-03-04
(where backlog bonanza can cover both old PR review and MCP review)
Hmm, I'm trying to think if there's any place to go through unimplemented or partially implemented features, akin to the lang backlog bananza
Wow what ninja
yes that is also a kind of backlog, definitely
@Jack Huey do you think we should make a document ahead of time to drive the backlog bonanza? Or just rely on github searches at the time of the meeting itself?
Good question. Probably a doc would be good
Even if it's mostly auto generated
Right, what I meant by "github searches" was more: Populate a document by the output of certain github searches
and then fill in the document with extra notes as we go through the meeting
(much like T-lang)
so the main task ahead of time would be deciding about what scope is appropriate and what github searches to use for the initial doc construction
That's probably sufficient
Okay.
Should we talk about scope here and now? Or defer to a separate topic
yeah, I don't know. I was assuming the scope might end up being determined in part by the number of items in each category
which means its probably best to handle that asynchronously
@Wesley Wiser what do you think? I suppose there could be some value to saying "we're just going cover X", whether X is "old PRs" or "partially implemented features", etc
We have time now it seems, so I don't see a reason not to hash it out here.
We might get more engagement/excitement about the meeting itself if its focused on feature dev
(and that might actually be a good thing to focus on two weeks after the Ambitiions doc)
We already cover old PRs to some extent during the triage meeting each week, I would put those last personally.
so lets see, what is the best way to see the features and their status. :)
Something like this perhaps? https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AT-compiler+label%3AC-tracking-issue
seems like a good stgart
niko constructed this thing for T-lang: https://github.com/orgs/rust-lang/projects/16/views/4
it might be interesting to see if we could build something analogous for T-compielr
but the link Wesley provided certainly seems like it has enough meat on it to drive an hour long meeting. :)

Actually, excluding the other teams' labels might be a better approach. I'm seeing stuff that is probably within our team's scope that isn't tagged T-compiler with this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?page=2&q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AC-tracking-issue+-label%3AT-libs-api+-label%3AT-libs+-label%3AT-lang+-label%3AT-rustdoc
So, who's going to own the prep work for the 2022-03-04 backlog meeting?
I can do it, but I might want help
I'm happy to work on that unless someone else wants to :smile:
Though to be honest, the prep work might just be converting Wesley's github query into a hackmd format. :)
We'll figure it out
If anyone else wants to assist, ping @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser somewhere. :)
But with that, I think we've got our plan

• 2022-02-18: Review 2022 Ambititions for T-Compiler compiler-team#483
  • 2022-03-04: Compiler Feature Backlog Bonanza compiler-team#484
I'll go make an issue for the latter right now
But I think this planning meeting is over, in that case. Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!
hey @simulacrum (or maybe someone else from core), would you mind rubber-stamping https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/932 for me?
taking a look
(I should have put it together 6 days ago, so that's my bad.)
thanks!
done
